name: Alim Qasimov
description:
'''Alim Hamza oghlu Qasimov''' ({{langx|az|Alim Həmzə oğlu Qasımov}}; born August 14, 1957) is an [[Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]] musician and one of the most major [[mugham]] singers in [[Azerbaijan]]. He was awarded the [[International Music Council]]-[[UNESCO]] Music Prize in 1999, one of the highest international prizes for music. His music is characterized by his vocal [[musical improvisation|improvisation]] and represents a move away from the traditional style of mugham. Qasimov has recorded nine albums, three of which are mugham albums with his daughter, [[Farghana Qasimova]].

According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', "Qasimov is simply one of the greatest singers alive, with a searing spontaneity that conjures passion and devotion, contemplation and incantation."

He joined fellow Azerbaijani [[Sabina Babayeva]] on stage at the Grand Finale of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]] in [[Baku]] to sing back vocals for her entry, "[[When the Music Dies]]." Additionally, Qasimov was featured as part of the opening act of the Grand Final.
